{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3347273,"name":"Greg","username":"JoeFizzy","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/958977/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-29T17:18:47.592Z","cooked":"

We’re trying to add PoseEstimation to our robot using YAGSL and LimeLight and are getting some inconsistent results. First, here’s the code we are using:

  public void updateVisionOdometry() {
    LimelightHelpers.PoseEstimate limeLightMeasurement = LimelightHelpers.getBotPoseEstimate_wpiBlue("limelight");

    if(limeLightMeasurement.tagCount >= 2) {
      swerveDrive.addVisionMeasurement(limeLightMeasurement.pose, limeLightMeasurement.timestampSeconds, VecBuilder.fill(5, 5,99999));
      //swerveDrive.addVisionMeasurement(limeLightMeasurement.pose, limeLightMeasurement.timestampSeconds);
      SmartDashboard.putNumber("limelightvision.pose.x", limeLightMeasurement.pose.getX());
      SmartDashboard.putNumber("limelightvision.pose.y", limeLightMeasurement.pose.getY());
      SmartDashboard.putNumber("limelightvision.pose.Rotation", limeLightMeasurement.pose.getRotation().getDegrees());
    }
  }

Our code is here for reference.

When I look at the “limelightvision.pose.x” values in Network Tables, they look good and are stable.

When I look at the swervedrive.pose.x values in Network Tables, they are not consistent and constantly move +/- 2m when the robot is standing still (see video below):

Google Photos

New video by Family Photos

In this video, the x,y position of the robot (as measured by limelight) is (14.9,4.2) but you can see the pose(x) from odometry swinging from 13.5 - 16 (roughly). This is with the robot sitting still.

I suspect it has something to do with the standard deviations (VecBuilder.fill(5, 5,99999)) in the addVisionMeasurement() method. I originally tried this method with values of (0.7, 0.7, 99999) based on someone else’s code, but the variations were much wilder (sometimes hundreds of thousands of meters off).

Based on this information, I have a few questions:

Does this seem logical? Is the Standard Deviations where to look to tune this issue?

Are there better Standard Deviation values to use (without spending months tuning and testing)?

Is this a feasible way to measure robot pose on the field in both Auto and Tele (given that we have 1 week until States and 3 weeks until Worlds)?

Thanks in advance-

@nstrike -

I originally started out with the same code that @dylan292 referenced. With this code, we noticed shifting of the x/y coordinates when the robot was standing still (again, the Limelight measurements were not shifting at all).

As part of our troubleshooting process, we removed the Standard Deviations completely and it was significantly worse. The robot was undriveable because the Adjusted IMU Yaw value was constantly changing – the Raw IMU Yaw value was stable. This caused the robot to drive in circles because it thought it’s rotation was changing.

We’re pretty confident the variability in our pose is caused by the Standard Deviations – Just trying to figure out how to measure/calculate/derive workable values.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-03-30T12:52:59.732Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":60,"readers_count":59,"score":22.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":460619,"topic_slug":"poseestimation-error-with-yagsl-and-limelight","display_username":"Greg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62319,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/poseestimation-error-with-yagsl-and-limelight/460619/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3347769,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-30T13:44:14.422Z","cooked":"

We handle the timing possibly different than you. We also vary the std devs a little depending on auto, disabled, teleop, valid pose.

 poseEstimator.addVisionMeasurement(
      camera.getBotPoseBlue().toPose2d(), 
      Timer.getFPGATimestamp() - (camera.getTotalLatencyBlue() / 1000),
      visionStdDevs.times(camera.getAverageDistanceFromTarget()));

    public void configStdDevs() // base values
    {
        stateStdDevs.set(0, 0, 0.1);    // x (meters)
        stateStdDevs.set(1, 0, 0.1);    // y (meters)
        stateStdDevs.set(2, 0, 0.05);   // heading (radians)

        visionStdDevs.set(0, 0, 0.9);   // x (meters
        visionStdDevs.set(1, 0, 0.9);   // y (meters)
        visionStdDevs.set(2, 0, 0.95);  // heading (radians)
    }

Adjusted IMU Yaw

What gyro are you using? What version of YAGSL are you using?
